accussed_details.name: Muhammad Hussain
allegation: Violation of Section 18(a) read with Section 27 of the Drugs Act, 1940

complaint_summary: Muhammad Hussain was accused of stocking sub-standard drugs at his medical store, violating Section 18(a) read with Section 27 of the Drugs Act, 1940. Samples taken by the Inspector of Drugs revealed foreign particles and suspended material in the drugs.
investigation_summary: On 29-09-1975, Inspector Munawar Iqbal inspected Hussain Medical Store in Village Bakhshan Khan, Tehsil Chishtian, District Bahawalnagar, and collected samples of Chloroquine N.-W. F. P. Injection, Batch No. 59, manufactured by Messrs Kashmir Chemical Industries, Lahore. The samples were analyzed by the Drugs Testing Laboratory, Lahore, on 18-03-1976, which confirmed non-compliance with B.P. standards. Notice was issued to the appellant, but he failed to provide warranty or purchase invoice.
judgment_summary: The appellate court ruled that the Drug Court constituted under the Drugs Act, 1976 lacked jurisdiction to try offences under the repealed Drugs Act, 1940. Procedural changes affecting vested rights are not retrospective unless expressly stated. The conviction and sentence of Muhammad Hussain were declared illegal and set aside.
punishment: Conviction set aside; bail bond discharged.
Decision_or_verdict: Appeal allowed; conviction and sentence overturned.
legal_arguments: Drug Court under Drugs Act, 1976 lacked jurisdiction to try offences under Drugs Act, 1940.
Section 6(e) of the General Clauses Act, 1897 allows prosecution for offences under repealed laws unless explicitly barred.
Procedural changes affecting vested rights are not retrospective unless expressly stated.
Prosecution failed to prove intent (mens rea); onus of proof wrongly shifted.
witnesses: Muhammad Aslam (Employee of Ch. Medical Store)

witness_statement.Khadim Hussain: Prescribed Chloroquine Injection for malaria patients.
witness_statement.Shamshad Ahmad: Testified that appellant refused to sell prescribed medicine.
witness_statement.Muhammad Aslam: Denied handwriting and signature on warranty document.

key_issues: Jurisdiction of Drug Court under Drugs Act, 1976

maxims.Retrospective Procedural Law: Procedural laws are retrospective unless affecting vested rights.

legal_terms.Mens Rea: Mental state indicating intention or knowledge of wrongdoing.

words_and_phrases.Sub-standard Drugs: Drugs failing to meet prescribed quality standards.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around jurisdictional issues arising from the repeal of the Drugs Act, 1940 and its replacement by the Drugs Act, 1976. The appellate court ruled that procedural changes affecting vested rights are not retrospective unless explicitly stated. The conviction was overturned due to lack of jurisdiction by the Drug Court under the new law.

facts.location: Hussain Medical Store, Village Bakhshan Khan, Tehsil Chishtian, District Bahawalnagar
facts.analysis_result: Did not conform to B.P. Standard due to suspended material and foreign particles

appellant.jurisdiction_challenge: Drug Court constituted under Drugs Act, 1976 had no jurisdiction to try offences under repealed Drugs Act, 1940.
appellant.merits_challenge: Stocking sub-standard drugs without warranty is not punishable under Drugs Ordinance, 1976 or Drugs Act, 1976.
appellant.mens_rea: Prosecution failed to prove intent; onus of proof wrongly shifted.

respondent.general_clauses_act: Section 6(e) of General Clauses Act, 1897 allows prosecution for offences under repealed enactments.

key_findings.jurisdiction: Drug Court under Drugs Act, 1976 lacked jurisdiction to try offences under Drugs Act, 1940.
key_findings.procedural_law: Procedural changes affecting vested rights are not retrospective unless expressly stated.
key_findings.penal_statutes: Penal statutes must be strictly construed in favor of the accused.

judgment.decision: Conviction and sentence set aside; bail bond discharged.
